students_response:
It was a sunny Sunday morning , the sun shone brillantly in the clear blue sky . Sarah jumped out of bed and got ready to go out. She ran down the stairs and quikly devoured her breakfast ." Mom , let's go ! " Sarah exclaimed . Sarah's Mother had promised Sarah that they would get to adopt a dog today . Sarah had saved up money from the previous yer and will be using it to adopt a dog . 
 Once they reached the adopting centre , Sarah and her mother were greeted with barks . Sarah skipped down the aisle of dog and look at each of them but none of the dogs seem to be catching her attention . Soon, Sarah noticed a dog that caught her attention . It had brown fur , it's eyes were big and round and it was very skinny . The dog stared at Sarah as though asking her to take it home . 
 Sarah deceied to take the dog home. She placed her savings on the counter to pay. From that day onwards Sarah took great care of the dog.

students_response: \nIn our rapidly developing society, a child's future is often regarded as the top priority of parents. Many parents hope their children have bright and sustainable futures, and this is often only possible when students ace their examinations. As Singapore is a meritocratic society, only the top percentile can attain the best standard of education. As such, parents often push their children to strive for better grades. However, this pursuit would lead to a highly competitive learning environment where, on one hand, students would find themselves in such an overwhelming learning environment, leading to students having excessive stress and mental strain. Likewise, parents may disapprove of such an overly competitive learning environment, fearing that it might promote an unhealthy perception of education. Meanwhile, governments view competition in schools as a way to find and nurture national talent. Similarly, tuition companies may support a competitive education system, as it motivates worrisome parents to seek extra academic support, ultimately boosting their business. While it is clear that unhealthy competition can be harmful to students, a well-managed and positive competitive environment can motivate learners and bring out their full potential. Therefore, when implemented strategically, competition in schools can be beneficial.\n

However, this pursuit would lead to a highly competitive learning environment where, on one hand, students would find themselves in such an overwhelming learning environment, leading to students having excessive stress and mental strain. Likewise, parents may disapprove of such an overly competitive learning environment, fearing that it might promote an unhealthy perception of education. Therefore, when implemented strategically, <tag id="1">competition in schools can be beneficial</tag>.

Therefore, when implemented strategically, competition in schools can be beneficial.'

students_response: \nIn our rapidly developing society, a child's future is often regarded as the top priority of parents. Many parents hope their children have bright and sustainable futures, and this is often only possible when students ace their examinations. As Singapore is a meritocratic society, only the top percentile can attain the best standard of education. As such, parents often push their children to strive for better grades. However, this pursuit would lead to a highly competitive learning environment where, on one hand, students would find themselves in such an overwhelming learning environment, leading to students having excessive stress and mental strain. Likewise, parents may disapprove of such an overly competitive learning environment, fearing that it might promote an unhealthy perception of education. Meanwhile, governments view competition in schools as a way to find and nurture national talent. Similarly, tuition companies may support a competitive education system, as it motivates worrisome parents to seek extra academic support, ultimately boosting their business. While it is clear that unhealthy competition can be harmful to students, a well-managed and positive competitive environment can motivate learners and bring out their full potential. Therefore, when implemented strategically, competition in schools can be beneficial.\n

students_response:
I have always been afraid of Dobermanns. Their sharp teeth,strong bodies,and dark eyes made them look dangerous. Whenever I saw one, my stomach twisted, and I wanted to run in the other direction.

 One day, I decided I did not want to be afraid anymore. My bestfriend, Olivia, had a Dobermann puppy named Crunchy." He is very friendly,"Olivia said."Come and meet him."I felt nervous, but I agreed.

 That afternoon, as I stepped outside, I suddenly heard loud barking. I looked up and froze. A man was walking past with a large Dobermann on a lead. It fixed its sharp eyes on me and led out a deep,booming bark that echoed through the streets. My whole body tensed. My hands turned clammy , and my heart pounded against my chest.

 "Stay calm...do not run..."I told myself, but my legs trembled, ready to bolt. I gripped the hen of my shirt tightly, my mind racing. What if it chased me? What if it bit me? The dog took a step forward, ears perked. I swallowed hard, my breath coming in short, I panicked gasps.

 Then, I remembered why I was here. I had to face my fear. Slowly, I took a deep breath and stepped forward, my heart still beating a little too fast. The Dobermann sat calmly in front of me, its bark eyes watched me curiously. I hesitated, then stretched out my hand.

 The dog sniffed my fingers before pressing its cold, wet nose against my palm. A shaky smile spread across my face as I exhaled, the tension in my shoulders easing ."You are not so scary after all,"I whispered, stroking its sleek fur.

 A wave of warmth filled my chest. I had faced my fear, and it no longer controlled me.

Text mismatch: Original and annotated passages differ when tags are removed. Original: 'I have always been afraid of Dobermanns. Their sharp teeth,strong bodies,and dark eyes made them look dangerous. Whenever I saw one, my stomach twisted, and I wanted to run in the other direction.

 One day, I decided I did not want to be afraid anymore. My bestfriend, Olivia, had a Dobermann puppy named Crunchy." He is very friendly,"Olivia said."Come and meet him."I felt nervous, but I agreed.

 That afternoon, as I stepped outside, I suddenly heard loud barking. I looked up and froze. A man was walking past with a large Dobermann on a lead. It fixed its sharp eyes on me and led out a deep,booming bark that echoed through the streets. My whole body tensed. My hands turned clammy , and my heart pounded against my chest.

 "Stay calm...do not run..."I told myself, but my legs trembled, ready to bolt. I gripped the hen of my shirt tightly, my mind racing. What if it chased me? What if it bit me? The dog took a step forward, ears perked. I swallowed hard, my breath coming in short, I panicked gasps.

 Then, I remembered why I was here. I had to face my fear. Slowly, I took a deep breath and stepped forward, my heart still beating a little too fast. The Dobermann sat calmly in front of me, its bark eyes watched me curiously. I hesitated, then stretched out my hand.

 The dog sniffed my fingers before pressing its cold, wet nose against my palm. A shaky smile spread across my face as I exhaled, the tension in my shoulders easing ."You are not so scary after all,"I whispered, stroking its sleek fur.

 A wave of warmth filled my chest. I had faced my fear, and it no longer controlled me.

Text mismatch: Original and annotated passages differ when tags are removed. Original: 'I have always been afraid of Dobermanns. Their sharp teeth,strong bodies,and dark eyes made them look dangerous. Whenever I saw one, my stomach twisted, and I wanted to run in the other direction.

 One day, I decided I did not want to be afraid anymore. My bestfriend, Olivia, had a Dobermann puppy named Crunchy." He is very friendly,"Olivia said."Come and meet him."I felt nervous, but I agreed.

 That afternoon, as I stepped outside, I suddenly heard loud barking. I looked up and froze. A man was walking past with a large Dobermann on a lead. It fixed its sharp eyes on me and led out a deep,booming bark that echoed through the streets. My whole body tensed. My hands turned clammy , and my heart pounded against my chest.

 "Stay calm...do not run..."I told myself, but my legs trembled, ready to bolt. I gripped the hen of my shirt tightly, my mind racing. What if it chased me? What if it bit me? The dog took a step forward, ears perked. I swallowed hard, my breath coming in short, I panicked gasps.

 Then, I remembered why I was here. I had to face my fear. Slowly, I took a deep breath and stepped forward, my heart still beating a little too fast. The Dobermann sat calmly in front of me, its bark eyes watched me curiously. I hesitated, then stretched out my hand.

 The dog sniffed my fingers before pressing its cold, wet nose against my palm. A shaky smile spread across my face as I exhaled, the tension in my shoulders easing ."You are not so scary after all,"I whispered, stroking its sleek fur.

 A wave of warmth filled my chest. I had faced my fear, and it no longer controlled me.

I had faced my fear, and it no longer controlled me.'

 Then, I remembered why I was here. I had to face my fear. Slowly, I took a deep breath and stepped forward, my heart still beating a little too fast. The Dobermann sat calmly in front of me, its bark eyes watched me curiously. I hesitated, then stretched out my hand.

 The dog sniffed my fingers before pressing its cold, wet nose against my palm. A shaky smile spread across my face as I exhaled, the tension in my shoulders easing ."You are not so scary after all,"I whispered, stroking its sleek fur.

 A wave of warmth filled my chest. I had faced my fear, and it no longer controlled me.

 One day, I decided I did not want to be afraid anymore. My bestfriend, Olivia, had a Dobermann puppy named Crunchy." He is very friendly,"Olivia said."Come and meet him."I felt nervous, but I agreed.

 That afternoon, as I stepped outside, I suddenly heard loud barking. I looked up and froze. A man was walking past with a large Dobermann on a lead. It fixed its sharp eyes on me and led out a deep,booming bark that echoed through the streets. My whole body tensed. My hands turned clammy , and my heart pounded against my chest.

 "Stay calm...do not run..."I told myself, but my legs trembled, ready to bolt. I gripped the hen of my shirt tightly, my mind racing. What if it chased me? What if it bit me? The dog took a step forward, ears perked. I swallowed hard, my breath coming in short, I panicked gasps.

 Then, I remembered why I was here. I had to face my fear. Slowly, I took a deep breath and stepped forward, my heart still beating a little too fast. The Dobermann sat calmly in front of me, its bark eyes watched me curiously. I hesitated, then stretched out my hand.

 The dog sniffed my fingers before pressing its cold, wet nose against my palm. A shaky smile spread across my face as I exhaled, the tension in my shoulders easing ."You are not so scary after all,"I whispered, stroking its sleek fur.

 A wave of warmth filled my chest. I had faced my fear, and it no longer controlled me.

students_response:
Where has my parrot gone? Amy, Dans older sister, exclaimed frantically. It was just after dinner and Amy had returned to her bedroom to feed her parrot only to find the cage open, empty and had a single red feather from her parrot inside it. Oh no! She thought, My parents are not going to let me keep a pet ever again if I dont find out who did it! 
 Instantaneously, she sprung into action to try and find out who did it. First, she thought that she might not have locked the cage properly due to her carelessness but recalled clearly that she did lock the cage. Then, she started looking around the cage to see if there were any clues left behind by the culprit. Meanwhile, her younger brother had heard her shout. Waves of anxiety swept through him as he was the one who had set the bird free as he was watching and feeding it without his sisters permission. At the birdcage, Amy found a piece of cloth with red and white stripes on it that looked like it had been torn off a shirt. She pondered whether the cloth could have been torn off the culprits shirt when they freed the bird.
 However, she could not rule anyone out yet as everyone in the family all had red and white striped shirts to wear on national day and they all had tears on them due to various accidents that happened. Below the cage, she found a packet of half-empty bird seeds as if someone was feeding the parrot before it escaped and also an overturned stool. She thought that it might have been her brother as he was the only one who needed a stool to unlock the cage but realised that it could not be him as he did not have the key to unlock the cage. 
 Amy then thought to check the security camera her parents had installed and noticed that there was a person standing near the cage at around 7 o'clock at night. She zoomed in on the figure and discovered that the person was short and standing near the cage. Although she could not see what he or she was doing, there was a loud squawk soon afterwards as the parrot escaped.
 Then, realisation dawned on Amy as she hurried to the place where she kept the keys and discovered the key was missing and there was only the spare key left. Realising her own brother had done it, she stormed up the stairs furiously and slammed open her brothers bedroom door. When Amy opened the door, the waves of rage in her was palpable as she accused her brother indignantly, I knew you let my parrot escape! I I didn't do it! Dan said shakily. Yes you did! There was a piece of the cloth that you are wearing now and also a stool which you used to steal my keys! Amy said angrily. I am going to tell mom and dad!
 The anxiety that coursed through Dan like a wave was palpable as he stuttered over his words. He did set the parrot free but only accidentally as he wanted to feed it at least once.
 In the end, Amys parents ordered Dan to pay back the money used to buy the parrot out of his own pocket money and apologize to Amy. She forgave him and decided to put this incident aside and let bygones be bygones.

Below the cage, she found a packet of half-empty bird seeds as if someone was feeding the parrot before it escaped and also an overturned stool. She thought that it might have been her brother as he was the only one who needed a stool to unlock the cage but realised that it could not be him as he did not have the key to unlock the cage. 
 Amy then thought to check the security camera her parents had installed and noticed that there was a person standing near the cage at around 7 o'clock at night. She zoomed in on the figure and discovered that the person was short and standing near the cage. Although she could not see what he or she was doing, there was a loud squawk soon afterwards as the parrot escaped.
 Then, realisation dawned on Amy as she hurried to the place where she kept the keys and discovered the key was missing and there was only the spare key left. Realising her own brother had done it, she stormed up the stairs furiously and slammed open her brothers bedroom door. When Amy opened the door, the waves of rage in her was palpable as she accused her brother indignantly, I knew you let my parrot escape! I I didn't do it! Dan said shakily. Yes you did! There was a piece of the cloth that you are wearing now and also a stool which you used to steal my keys! Amy said angrily. I am going to tell mom and dad!
 The anxiety that coursed through Dan like a wave was palpable as he stuttered over his words. He did set the parrot free but only accidentally as he wanted to feed it at least once.
 In the end, Amys parents ordered Dan to pay back the money used to buy the parrot out of his own pocket money and apologize to Amy. She forgave him and decided to put this incident aside and let bygones be bygones.

Then, she started looking around the cage to see if there were any clues left behind by the culprit. Meanwhile, her younger brother had heard her shout. Waves of anxiety swept through him as he was the one who had set the bird free as he was watching and feeding it without his sister's permission. At the birdcage, Amy found a piece of cloth with red and white stripes on it that looked like it had been torn off a shirt.  Amy then thought to check the security camera her parents had installed and noticed that there was a person standing near the cage at around 7 o'clock at night. She zoomed in on the figure and discovered that the person was short and standing near the cage. Although she could not see what he or she was doing, there was a loud squawk soon afterwards as the parrot escaped.

Realising her own brother had done it, she stormed up the stairs furiously and slammed open her brother's bedroom door. When Amy opened the door, the waves of rage in her was palpable as she accused her brother indignantly, "I knew you let my parrot escape!" "I I didn't do it!" Dan said shakily. "Yes you did! There was a piece of the cloth that you are wearing now and also a stool which you used to steal my keys!" Amy said angrily. "I am going to tell mom and dad!" The anxiety that coursed through Dan like a wave was palpable as he stuttered over his words. He did set the parrot free but only accidentally as he wanted to feed it at least once. In the end, Amy's parents ordered Dan to pay back the money used to buy the parrot out of his own pocket money and apologize to Amy. She forgave him and decided to put this incident aside and let bygones be bygones.'

Where has my parrot gone? Amy, Dans older sister, exclaimed frantically. Then, she started looking around the cage to see if there were any clues left behind by the culprit. Meanwhile, her younger brother had heard her shout. Waves of anxiety swept through him as he was the one who had set the bird free as he was watching and feeding it without his sisters permission. At the birdcage, Amy found a piece of cloth with red and white stripes on it that looked like it had been torn off a shirt. She pondered whether the cloth could have been torn off the culprits shirt when they freed the bird.
 However, she could not rule anyone out yet as everyone in the family all had red and white striped shirts to wear on national day and they all had tears on them due to various accidents that happened. Below the cage, she found a packet of half-empty bird seeds as if someone was feeding the parrot before it escaped and also an overturned stool. She thought that it might have been her brother as he was the only one who needed a stool to unlock the cage but realised that it could not be him as he did not have the key to unlock the cage. 
 Amy then thought to check the security camera her parents had installed and noticed that there was a person standing near the cage at around 7 o'clock at night. She zoomed in on the figure and discovered that the person was short and standing near the cage. Although she could not see what he or she was doing, there was a loud squawk soon afterwards as the parrot escaped.
 Then, realisation dawned on Amy as she hurried to the place where she kept the keys and discovered the key was missing and there was only the spare key left. Realising her own brother had done it, she stormed up the stairs furiously and slammed open her brothers bedroom door. When Amy opened the door, the waves of rage in her was palpable as she accused her brother indignantly, I knew you let my parrot escape! I I didn't do it! Dan said shakily. Yes you did! There was a piece of the cloth that you are wearing now and also a stool which you used to steal my keys! Amy said angrily. I am going to tell mom and dad!
 The anxiety that coursed through Dan like a wave was palpable as he stuttered over his words. He did set the parrot free but only accidentally as he wanted to feed it at least once.
 In the end, Amys parents ordered Dan to pay back the money used to buy the parrot out of his own pocket money and apologize to Amy. She forgave him and decided to put this incident aside and let bygones be bygones.

students_response: At home, I was lying down in bed and stared blankly at the ceiling. At the corner of my eye, I saw a photograph that caught my attention. I got up and walked to it, upon taking a look at the photograph, I saw me holding a test paper with full marks. I thought about it, but I could not recall anything. As I walked back to my bed, I suddenly recalled the moment in the photograph and the momories came flashing back\n

students_response: No, not everyone can deserve a second chance for what they did especially if it has damaged someones life for no good reason. Bullies often just do the work they are needed to do for their actions but they dont learn from it. If they have caused harm to someones life trying to be \"cool\" or \"impress\" people they should not be given a second chance as it is not fair to the person who got bullied. If they truely changed and feel regret and guilt they should first make up to the person they bullied and prevent others from facing the same thing. That truely shoes that they care\n

students_response:
One sunny afternoon Kevin and caleb went out to the playground and play. they were having fun playing in the playground . 

As caleb and kevin was about to go to the toilet they saw a lonely boy siting down in the pavement crying . kevin ask caleb "why is he crying ? shall we go ask him why is he crying?. caleb said "ok come lets go." . They went to the boy and ask "dear boy why are you sitting in the pavement alone and crying ? " .The boy said " when i was playing in the play playground I was thirsty so i wanted to go to my parents to drink some water as i was going my parents was not there i was so scared i tried searching for them but i could not find them instead i waited over here and see if they came." kevin said " ok don't worry me and my friend caleb will help you find you parents."

 Kevin ,caleb and the boy was searching for the boy's parents they were searching up and down left and right but stil no sign no sign of them .The boy was hoping when will he find his parents .when they when back to the playground there was no sign of them .As the boy turned right alas they found his parents he ran to his parents and hugged them so tight.The boy's parents found the two boys and said thank you to them the two boys was so happy that they helped someone in need .

students_response:
It was a sunny Sunday morning , the sun shone brillantly in the clear blue sky . Sarah jumped out of bed and got ready to go out. She ran down the stairs and quikly devoured her breakfast ." Mom , let's go ! " Sarah exclaimed . Sarah's Mother had promised Sarah that they would get to adopt a dog today . Sarah had saved up money from the previous yer and will be using it to adopt a dog . 
 Once they reached the adopting centre , Sarah and her mother were greeted with barks . Sarah skipped down the aisle of dog and look at each of them but none of the dogs seem to be catching her attention . Soon, Sarah noticed a dog that caught her attention . It had brown fur , it's eyes were big and round and it was very skinny . The dog stared at Sarah as though asking her to take it home . 
 Sarah deceied to take the dog home. She placed her savings on the counter to pay. From that day onwards Sarah took great care of the dog.

Sarah skipped down the aisle of dog and look at each of them but none of the dogs seem to be catching her attention . Soon, Sarah noticed a dog that caught her attention . It had brown fur , it's eyes were big and round and it was very skinny . The dog stared at Sarah as though asking her to take it home . Sarah deceied to take the dog home. She placed her savings on the counter to pay. From that day onwards Sarah took great care of the dog.'

students_response:
"That's it. That dog has to go. I'm sick and tired of it destroying the things in the
 house, especially the shoes!"
"But..." Danny
I tried to interject.
"No 'but'!" his mother stormed. Danny's mother had ranted and raved about this before. However, this time, I detected the steely tone in her voice. Before long, it spelt doom for me.
Soon, I would be separated from Danny, my optimistic, fun-loving master whom I adored with all my doggy heart. Danny was protesting, tears glazing his eyes. His mothers voice had now risen to fever pitch. What was I to do? I knew I had tried to behave. Well, except for one thing  I had the habit of chewing things.

 I flattened my body on the floor, laid my head on my paws and whined. I looked at him mournfully. My legs had turned into mush because of the fear that seized my heart.
Im taking him for a walk, Danny muttered, blinking away unshed tears.
Walking beside Danny, birds flew free in the sky and chirped aloud their cheeky calls. It was an idyllic scene.
Danny! someone yelled. It was Mothers close friend. She was out walking with a baby in a pram.
Hi, Mrs. Deepak! Danny shouted as he ran up the slope towards her. As she chatted with Danny, she rocked the pram gently to soothe the baby.
Suddenly, my hackles rose with a tingling premonition. 
 A little boy on a bicycle swerved past unsteadily and knocked Mrs. Deepak's arm. She lost her grip on the pram, and it went rolling down the slope with the baby still inside. I caught a glimpse of the look of horror on her face, as if it had been etched on white marble. My canine instincts had proven right. With a loud bark, I bounded forward, jerking the lead out of Danny's hands in that split second. The lead streamed behind me as I raced after the runaway pram. With an extra burst of energy, I shot level with the pram. Snapping my jaws over one side of the handlebar, I dug into the ground with my paws. The pram's momentum dragged me a little, but to my utmost relief, the wheels slowed, then halted entirely. 
Mrs. Deepak rushed over, her trembling hands scooping the unharmed baby from the pram. Danny caught up, breathless, and clipped my lead back on. "Good boy!" he panted, ruffling my fur. Mrs. Deepak thanked me with tearful eyes, and I wagged my tailjust another day in the life of a dog whod finally earned his extra-large biscuit.
 To my utmost relief, it stopped safely. Surprisingly, the baby was gurgling. Running feet pounded up as Mrs. Deepak dashed to pick up her baby, Danny right on her heels. "Oh, Danny! Your wonderful dog saved my baby!" Mrs. Deepak repeated, clasping the baby to her bosom. Later, I learned Danny had poured out his woes to her earlier. That was why she insisted on accompanying him home to speak to his mother about me. When Dannys mother looked at me, I responded with a bark. Her eyes softened, and she agreed I deserved a second chance. I was allowed to stay! 

A week later, Mrs. Deepak gifted me a gnawing bone shaped like a pair of shoes to show her gratitude. It even tasted like shoes! My act of heroism paid off, and peace finally reigned in the household.

I tried to interject.
"No 'but'!" his mother stormed. Danny's mother had ranted and raved about this before. However, this time, I detected the steely tone in her voice. Before long, it spelt doom for me.
Soon, I would be separated from Danny, my optimistic, fun-loving master whom I adored with all my doggy heart. Danny was protesting, tears glazing his eyes. His mothers voice had now risen to fever pitch. What was I to do? I knew I had tried to behave. Well, except for one thing  I had the habit of chewing things.

 I flattened my body on the floor, laid my head on my paws and whined. I looked at him mournfully. My legs had turned into mush because of the fear that seized my heart.
Im taking him for a walk, Danny muttered, blinking away unshed tears.
Walking beside Danny, birds flew free in the sky and chirped aloud their cheeky calls. It was an idyllic scene.
Danny! someone yelled. It was Mothers close friend. She was out walking with a baby in a pram.
Hi, Mrs. Deepak! Danny shouted as he ran up the slope towards her. As she chatted with Danny, she rocked the pram gently to soothe the baby.
Suddenly, my hackles rose with a tingling premonition. 
 A little boy on a bicycle swerved past unsteadily and knocked Mrs. Deepak's arm. She lost her grip on the pram, and it went rolling down the slope with the baby still inside. I caught a glimpse of the look of horror on her face, as if it had been etched on white marble. My canine instincts had proven right. With a loud bark, I bounded forward, jerking the lead out of Danny's hands in that split second. The lead streamed behind me as I raced after the runaway pram. With an extra burst of energy, I shot level with the pram. Snapping my jaws over one side of the handlebar, I dug into the ground with my paws. The pram's momentum dragged me a little, but to my utmost relief, the wheels slowed, then halted entirely. 
Mrs. Deepak rushed over, her trembling hands scooping the unharmed baby from the pram. Danny caught up, breathless, and clipped my lead back on. "Good boy!" he panted, ruffling my fur. Mrs. Deepak thanked me with tearful eyes, and I wagged my tailjust another day in the life of a dog whod finally earned his extra-large biscuit.
 To my utmost relief, it stopped safely. Surprisingly, the baby was gurgling. Running feet pounded up as Mrs. Deepak dashed to pick up her baby, Danny right on her heels. "Oh, Danny! Your wonderful dog saved my baby!" Mrs. Deepak repeated, clasping the baby to her bosom. Later, I learned Danny had poured out his woes to her earlier. That was why she insisted on accompanying him home to speak to his mother about me. When Dannys mother looked at me, I responded with a bark. Her eyes softened, and she agreed I deserved a second chance. I was allowed to stay! 

A week later, Mrs. Deepak gifted me a gnawing bone shaped like a pair of shoes to show her gratitude. It even tasted like shoes! My act of heroism paid off, and peace finally reigned in the household.

The pram's momentum dragged me a little, but to my utmost relief, the wheels slowed, then halted entirely. Mrs. Deepak rushed over, her trembling hands scooping the unharmed baby from the pram. Danny caught up, breathless, and clipped my lead back on. "Good boy!" he panted, ruffling my fur. Mrs. Deepak thanked me with tearful eyes, and I wagged my tailjust another day in the life of a dog who'd finally earned his extra-large biscuit. To my utmost relief, it stopped safely. Surprisingly, the baby was gurgling. Running feet pounded up as Mrs. Deepak dashed to pick up her baby, Danny right on her heels. "Oh, Danny! Your wonderful dog saved my baby!" Mrs. Deepak repeated, clasping the baby to her bosom. Later, I learned Danny had poured out his woes to her earlier. That was why she insisted on accompanying him home to speak to his mother about me. When Danny's mother looked at me, I responded with a bark. Her eyes softened, and she agreed I deserved a second chance. I was allowed to stay! A week later, Mrs. Deepak gifted me a gnawing bone shaped like a pair of shoes to show her gratitude. It even tasted like shoes! My act of heroism paid off, and peace finally reigned in the household.'

students_response:
"That's it. That dog has to go. I'm sick and tired of it destroying the things in the
 house, especially the shoes!"
"But..." Danny
I tried to interject.
"No 'but'!" his mother stormed. Danny's mother had ranted and raved about this before. However, this time, I detected the steely tone in her voice. Before long, it spelt doom for me.
Soon, I would be separated from Danny, my optimistic, fun-loving master whom I adored with all my doggy heart. Danny was protesting, tears glazing his eyes. His mothers voice had now risen to fever pitch. What was I to do? I knew I had tried to behave. Well, except for one thing  I had the habit of chewing things.

 I flattened my body on the floor, laid my head on my paws and whined. I looked at him mournfully. My legs had turned into mush because of the fear that seized my heart.
Im taking him for a walk, Danny muttered, blinking away unshed tears.
Walking beside Danny, birds flew free in the sky and chirped aloud their cheeky calls. It was an idyllic scene.
Danny! someone yelled. It was Mothers close friend. She was out walking with a baby in a pram.
Hi, Mrs. Deepak! Danny shouted as he ran up the slope towards her. As she chatted with Danny, she rocked the pram gently to soothe the baby.
Suddenly, my hackles rose with a tingling premonition. 
 A little boy on a bicycle swerved past unsteadily and knocked Mrs. Deepak's arm. She lost her grip on the pram, and it went rolling down the slope with the baby still inside. I caught a glimpse of the look of horror on her face, as if it had been etched on white marble. My canine instincts had proven right. With a loud bark, I bounded forward, jerking the lead out of Danny's hands in that split second. The lead streamed behind me as I raced after the runaway pram. A week later, Mrs. Deepak gifted me a gnawing bone shaped like a pair of shoes to show her gratitude. It even tasted like shoes! My act of heroism paid off, and peace finally reigned in the household.

Soon, I would be separated from Danny, my optimistic, fun-loving master whom I adored with all my doggy heart. Danny was protesting, tears glazing his eyes. His mother's voice had now risen to fever pitch. What was I to do? I knew I had tried to behave. Well, except for one thing  I had the habit of chewing things. I flattened my body on the floor, laid my head on my paws and whined. I looked at him mournfully. My legs had turned into mush because of the fear that seized my heart. "I'm taking him for a walk," Danny muttered, blinking away unshed tears. Walking beside Danny, birds flew free in the sky and chirped aloud their cheeky calls. It was an idyllic scene. "Danny!" someone yelled. It was Mother's close friend. She was out walking with a baby in a pram. "Hi, Mrs. Deepak!" Danny shouted as he ran up the slope towards her. As she chatted with Danny, she rocked the pram gently to soothe the baby. Suddenly, my hackles rose with a tingling premonition. A little boy on a bicycle swerved past unsteadily and knocked Mrs. Deepak's arm. She lost her grip on the pram, and it went rolling down the slope with the baby still inside. I caught a glimpse of the look of horror on her face, as if it had been etched on white marble. My canine instincts had proven right. With a loud bark, I bounded forward, jerking the lead out of Danny's hands in that split second. The lead streamed behind me as I raced after the runaway pram. With an extra burst of energy, I shot level with the pram. Snapping my jaws over one side of the handlebar, I dug into the ground with my paws. The pram's momentum dragged me a little, but to my utmost relief, the wheels slowed, then halted entirely. Mrs. Deepak rushed over, her trembling hands scooping the unharmed baby from the pram. Danny caught up, breathless, and clipped my lead back on. "Good boy!" he panted, ruffling my fur. Mrs. Deepak thanked me with tearful eyes, and I wagged my tailjust another day in the life of a dog who'd finally earned his extra-large biscuit. To my utmost relief, it stopped safely. Surprisingly, the baby was gurgling. Running feet pounded up as Mrs. Deepak dashed to pick up her baby, Danny right on her heels. "Oh, Danny! Your wonderful dog saved my baby!" Mrs. Deepak repeated, clasping the baby to her bosom. Later, I learned Danny had poured out his woes to her earlier. That was why she insisted on accompanying him home to speak to his mother about me. When Danny's mother looked at me, I responded with a bark. Her eyes softened, and she agreed I deserved a second chance. I was allowed to stay! A week later, Mrs. Deepak gifted me a gnawing bone shaped like a pair of shoes to show her gratitude. It even tasted like shoes! My act of heroism paid off, and peace finally reigned in the household.'

With an extra burst of energy, I shot level with the pram. Snapping my jaws over one side of the handlebar, I dug into the ground with my paws. The pram's momentum dragged me a little, but to my utmost relief, the wheels slowed, then halted entirely. 
Mrs. Deepak rushed over, her trembling hands scooping the unharmed baby from the pram. Danny caught up, breathless, and clipped my lead back on. "Good boy!" he panted, ruffling my fur. Mrs. Deepak thanked me with tearful eyes, and I wagged my tailjust another day in the life of a dog whod finally earned his extra-large biscuit.
 To my utmost relief, it stopped safely. Surprisingly, the baby was gurgling. Running feet pounded up as Mrs. Deepak dashed to pick up her baby, Danny right on her heels. "Oh, Danny! Your wonderful dog saved my baby!" Mrs. Deepak repeated, clasping the baby to her bosom. Later, I learned Danny had poured out his woes to her earlier. That was why she insisted on accompanying him home to speak to his mother about me. When Dannys mother looked at me, I responded with a bark. Her eyes softened, and she agreed I deserved a second chance. I was allowed to stay! 

A week later, Mrs. Deepak gifted me a gnawing bone shaped like a pair of shoes to show her gratitude. It even tasted like shoes! My act of heroism paid off, and peace finally reigned in the household.

"No 'but'!" his mother stormed. Danny's mother had ranted and raved about this before. However, this time, I detected the steely tone in her voice. Before long, it spelt doom for me.
Soon, I would be separated from Danny, my optimistic, fun-loving master whom I adored with all my doggy heart. Danny was protesting, tears glazing his eyes. His mothers voice had now risen to fever pitch. What was I to do? I knew I had tried to behave. Well, except for one thing  I had the habit of chewing things.

 I flattened my body on the floor, laid my head on my paws and whined. I looked at him mournfully. My legs had turned into mush because of the fear that seized my heart.
Im taking him for a walk, Danny muttered, blinking away unshed tears.
Walking beside Danny, birds flew free in the sky and chirped aloud their cheeky calls. It was an idyllic scene.
Danny! someone yelled. It was Mothers close friend. She was out walking with a baby in a pram.
Hi, Mrs. Deepak! Danny shouted as he ran up the slope towards her. As she chatted with Danny, she rocked the pram gently to soothe the baby.
Suddenly, my hackles rose with a tingling premonition. 
 A little boy on a bicycle swerved past unsteadily and knocked Mrs. Deepak's arm. She lost her grip on the pram, and it went rolling down the slope with the baby still inside. I caught a glimpse of the look of horror on her face, as if it had been etched on white marble. My canine instincts had proven right. With a loud bark, I bounded forward, jerking the lead out of Danny's hands in that split second. The lead streamed behind me as I raced after the runaway pram. With an extra burst of energy, I shot level with the pram. Snapping my jaws over one side of the handlebar, I dug into the ground with my paws. The pram's momentum dragged me a little, but to my utmost relief, the wheels slowed, then halted entirely. 
Mrs. Deepak rushed over, her trembling hands scooping the unharmed baby from the pram. Danny caught up, breathless, and clipped my lead back on. "Good boy!" he panted, ruffling my fur. Mrs. Deepak thanked me with tearful eyes, and I wagged my tailjust another day in the life of a dog whod finally earned his extra-large biscuit.
 To my utmost relief, it stopped safely. Surprisingly, the baby was gurgling. Running feet pounded up as Mrs. Deepak dashed to pick up her baby, Danny right on her heels. "Oh, Danny! Your wonderful dog saved my baby!" Mrs. Deepak repeated, clasping the baby to her bosom. Later, I learned Danny had poured out his woes to her earlier. That was why she insisted on accompanying him home to speak to his mother about me. When Dannys mother looked at me, I responded with a bark. Her eyes softened, and she agreed I deserved a second chance. I was allowed to stay! 

A week later, Mrs. Deepak gifted me a gnawing bone shaped like a pair of shoes to show her gratitude. It even tasted like shoes! My act of heroism paid off, and peace finally reigned in the household.

students_response: FTAs, or Free Trade Agreements, are treaties between two or more countries to reduce or eliminate trade barriers like tariffs and quotas, facilitating trade and investment. students_response:
**A Fearful Encounter**
It was already past 8 p.m. when my CCA finally ended. The sky was an inky blue, and the streetlights cast long, flickering shadows on the pavement. My bag felt heavy on my shoulders, and the usually familiar walk home seemed eerily quiet. I was the last one to leave school, and the silence made my footsteps sound louder than usual.
As I turned down the narrow lane that led to my block, I suddenly heard it  footsteps. Slow. Deliberate. Just behind me.
At first, I thought it was my imagination. I quickened my pace slightly, and the footsteps did too. A chill ran down my spine. I dared not look back. My heart began to pound, and my breaths came faster.
*Who could it be? Why were they following me?* 
I reached into my pocket for my phone, but my hands were trembling. The footsteps grew louder, quicker. I turned a sharp corner and broke into a run. My bag thumped against my back as I sprinted towards the main road, where I knew there would be people.
Then I heard a voice behind me, breathless. Wait! You dropped this!
I stopped in my tracks and spun around. A boy, around my age, was holding my water bottle. I had left it on the bench outside the school gate. His eyes widened in alarm, realizing he had frightened me.
Im so sorry! he said, holding up both hands in surrender. I didnt mean to scare youI just wanted to return this.
Relief flooded through me, mixed with embarrassment. I took the bottle and mumbled a thank you, still catching my breath. The fear that had gripped me moments ago faded, replaced by laughter  nervous, but genuine.
It was a fearful encounter, yes  but also a reminder that sometimes, our minds can turn shadows into monsters.

At first, I thought it was my imagination. I quickened my pace slightly, and the footsteps did too. A chill ran down my spine. I dared not look back. My heart began to pound, and my breaths came faster.
*Who could it be? Why were they following me?* 
I reached into my pocket for my phone, but my hands were trembling. The footsteps grew louder, quicker. I turned a sharp corner and broke into a run. My bag thumped against my back as I sprinted towards the main road, where I knew there would be people.
Then I heard a voice behind me, breathless. Wait! You dropped this!
I stopped in my tracks and spun around. A boy, around my age, was holding my water bottle. I had left it on the bench outside the school gate. His eyes widened in alarm, realizing he had frightened me.
Im so sorry! he said, holding up both hands in surrender. I didnt mean to scare youI just wanted to return this.
Relief flooded through me, mixed with embarrassment. I took the bottle and mumbled a thank you, still catching my breath. The fear that had gripped me moments ago faded, replaced by laughter  nervous, but genuine.
It was a fearful encounter, yes  but also a reminder that sometimes, our minds can turn shadows into monsters.

Why were they following me?* I reached into my pocket for my phone, but my hands were trembling. The footsteps grew louder, quicker. I turned a sharp corner and broke into a run. My bag thumped against my back as I sprinted towards the main road, where I knew there would be people. Then I heard a voice behind me, breathless. "Wait! You dropped this!" I stopped in my tracks and spun around. A boy, around my age, was holding my water bottle. I had left it on the bench outside the school gate. His eyes widened in alarm, realizing he had frightened me. "I'm so sorry!" he said, holding up both hands in surrender. "I didn't mean to scare youI just wanted to return this." Relief flooded through me, mixed with embarrassment. I took the bottle and mumbled a thank you, still catching my breath. The fear that had gripped me moments ago faded, replaced by laughter  nervous, but genuine. It was a fearful encounter, yes  but also a reminder that sometimes, our minds can turn shadows into monsters.'
